dt: {bc}an object usually of leather or feathers attached to a long cord and used by a {d_link|falconer|falconer} to recall or exercise a hawk

dt.t: may succumb to the {wi}lure{/wi} of candy, sodas and other sweets

dt: {bc}a decoy for attracting animals to capture: such as
{bc}an often luminous {dx_def}see {dxt|luminous||1a}{/dx_def} structure on the head of {d_link|pediculate|pediculate} fishes that is used to attract prey

et: Middle English, from Anglo-French {it}lure, leure{/it}, of Germanic origin; akin to Middle High German {it}luoder{/it} bait; perhaps akin to Old English {it}lathian{/it} to invite, Old High German {it}ladōn{/it}
shortdef: an object usually of leather or feathers attached to a long cord and used by a falconer to recall or exercise a hawk
an inducement to pleasure or gain : enticement

dt: {bc}to recall or exercise (a hawk) by means of a lure
{bc}to draw with a hint of pleasure or gain {bc}attract actively and strongly

pt: {sc}lure{/sc} {sc}entice{/sc} {sc}inveigle{/sc} {sc}decoy{/sc} {sc}tempt{/sc} {sc}seduce{/sc} mean to lead astray from one's true course. {sc}lure{/sc} implies a drawing into danger, evil, or difficulty through attracting and deceiving.
{sc}entice{/sc} suggests drawing by artful or adroit means.
{sc}inveigle{/sc} implies enticing by cajoling or flattering.
{sc}decoy{/sc} implies a luring into entrapment by artifice.

pt.t: attempting to {it}decoy{/it} the enemy into an ambush

pt: {sc}tempt{/sc} implies the presenting of an attraction so strong that it overcomes the restraints of conscience or better judgment.
{sc}seduce{/sc} implies a leading astray by persuasion or false promises.

shortdef: to recall or exercise (a hawk) by means of a lure
to draw with a hint of pleasure or gain : attract actively and strongly
